blunders.title: Kasparov vs Deep Blue - Game 6
blunders.description: In the decisive game of the rematch, Kasparov played an unsound bishop sacrifice that Deep Blue refuted. This blunder cost him the game and the match, marking the first time a world champion lost to a computer in a match.
blunders.analysis: Kasparov's Bxf7+ was a miscalculation. After Kxf7, White's attack doesn't compensate for the lost piece. Castling was the correct move, maintaining development and king safety.
blunders.lesson: Even the greatest players can miscalculate under pressure. Always verify that sacrifices are sound before playing them.

blunders.title: Fischer's Opening Blunder
blunders.description: In the first game of the 'Match of the Century', Fischer played a terrible bishop sacrifice that lost immediately. This was one of the worst blunders of his career.
blunders.analysis: Fischer's Bxh2 was a complete miscalculation. After Kxh2, Black has no follow-up and is simply down a piece. Nxd5 was the correct move, winning a pawn with a good position.
blunders.lesson: Even world champions can have terrible days. Always calculate carefully, especially in critical positions.

blunders.title: Kramnik's Mouse Slip
blunders.description: In a completely winning position, Kramnik accidentally moved his queen to d2 instead of e2 due to a mouse slip. This blunder allowed Deep Fritz to force a draw, costing Kramnik the game.
blunders.analysis: Qd2?? hangs the queen to ...Nxd4. Qe2 was the intended move, maintaining the winning advantage. This is a perfect example of why online chess requires extra care.
blunders.lesson: Always double-check your moves before confirming, especially in online play. One careless click can cost you the game.

blunders.title: Anand's Time Trouble Blunder
blunders.description: In severe time trouble, Anand played Re1, allowing a back-rank mate. This blunder effectively ended his chances of retaining the world championship title.
blunders.analysis: Re1?? allows ...Qd1#. Rf1 was necessary to prevent the back-rank mate. Time pressure caused one of the greatest players to miss a basic tactical pattern.
blunders.lesson: Time trouble is the great equalizer. Always be aware of back-rank weaknesses, especially when short on time.

blunders.title: Ivanchuk's Famous Blunder
blunders.description: Ivanchuk, known for his brilliant but sometimes erratic play, made a one-move blunder that lost his queen. This became one of the most famous blunders in modern chess.
blunders.analysis: Qd1?? hangs the queen to ...Nxd4. A simple oversight by a player capable of the most brilliant combinations. Even geniuses make basic mistakes.
blunders.lesson: No one is immune to simple oversights. Always check if your pieces are hanging before moving.

blunders.title: Fool's Mate - The Fastest Checkmate
blunders.description: Fool's Mate is the fastest possible checkmate in chess - just 2 moves! This happens when White plays the worst possible opening moves (f3 and g4), opening lines to their king. Black's queen delivers mate immediately.
blunders.analysis: After 1. f3 e5, White's 2. g4?? opens the diagonal to the king. Black's Qh4# is checkmate because the king has no escape squares and the pawn on g4 blocks the king's retreat. This is why f3 and g4 are considered terrible opening moves.
blunders.lesson: Never weaken your king's position in the opening. Develop pieces, control the center, and keep your king safe. f3 and g4 are among the worst first moves in chess.

blunders.title: Scholar's Mate - The 4-Move Checkmate
blunders.pgn: 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 Nc6 3. Qf3 Nf6?? 4. Qxf7#
blunders.description: Scholar's Mate is the most common beginner trap - a 4-move checkmate. White sets up a deadly attack with the queen and bishop, and Black falls for it by developing the knight to f6, blocking the f7 pawn's defense.
blunders.analysis: After 1. e4 e5 2. Bc4, White threatens Qf3 and Qxf7#. Black's 3...Nf6?? blocks the f7 pawn, allowing 4. Qxf7#. The correct defense is 3...Nc6 or 3...d6, defending f7. This trap works because f7 is the weakest square in Black's position (only defended by the king).
blunders.lesson: Always be aware of threats to f7 (for Black) or f2 (for White). These are the weakest squares in the opening. Develop pieces while maintaining king safety.

blunders.title: Legal's Mate - The Knight Sacrifice
blunders.pgn: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bc4 Bg4 4. Nc3 g6 5. Nxe5 Bxd1?? 6. Bxf7+ Ke7 7. Nd5#
blunders.description: Legal's Mate is a beautiful tactical pattern where White sacrifices the queen to deliver checkmate. Black falls for it by capturing the queen, allowing a forced mate sequence.
blunders.analysis: After 4...g6, White's 5. Nxe5! is a trap. If Black captures the queen with 5...Bxd1??, White has 6. Bxf7+ Ke7 7. Nd5#. The correct move is 5...Nxe4 or 5...Be7, avoiding the trap. This pattern is named after the 18th-century French player Legall de Kermeur.
blunders.lesson: Not all queen captures are good! Always check for checkmate threats before capturing material. A queen is worthless if you're mated.

blunders.title: The Two-Move Queen Loss
blunders.pgn: 1. e4 Qh4?? 2. Nf3 Qxe4+ 3. Be2 Qxg2 4. Bf3 Qxh1 5. Bxc7
blunders.description: A hilarious blunder where Black tries to copy Scholar's Mate but plays it on move 1, allowing White to develop with tempo and win the queen. This is what happens when you try fancy tricks without understanding them.
blunders.analysis: After 1. e4, Black's 1...Qh4?? is terrible. White simply plays 2. Nf3, attacking the queen and developing. Black's queen has no good squares and must retreat, losing time. White gets a huge development advantage. This shows why bringing the queen out early is usually bad.
blunders.lesson: Don't bring your queen out early! Develop your minor pieces first. The queen is too valuable to be chased around by knights and bishops.

blunders.title: The Three-Move Resignation
blunders.description: A spectacularly bad opening where Black plays two terrible moves in a row, allowing White to deliver checkmate in just 3 moves. This is what happens when you completely ignore opening principles.
blunders.analysis: After 1. e4, Black's 1...f6?? weakens the king's position. White's 2. d4 is normal development. Black's 2...g5?? is even worse, opening more lines to the king. White's 3. Qh5# is checkmate because the king has no escape and the pawns block retreat squares.
blunders.lesson: Opening principles exist for a reason! Control the center, develop pieces, and keep your king safe. Moves like f6 and g5 in the opening are terrible because they weaken your king's position.
